results.title: Phalaris seed retention
results.brief_description:
In order to negate Phelaris crops from losing their ‘top’ before harvesting, crop-dusting is employed.

Features good footage of plane flying over crops and releasing chemicals.

Largely comprises of an interview between a presenter and a scientist.

results.title: Phagocytes the body's defenders
results.brief_description: Photomicrography of the circulatory system and the processes of mitosis and phagocytosis. The film reveals how the body is protected from disease by the white blood corpuscles or leucocytes which engulf and destroy invading organisms.
results.description: Photomicrography of the circulatory system and the processes of mitosis and phagocytosis. The film reveals how the body is protected from disease by the white blood corpuscles or leucocytes which engulf and destroy invading organisms.

results.title: PEZ
results.brief_description: It’s a rare thing for a candy dispenser to become more famous than the candy it’s dispensing, but that’s certainly the case for PEZ. Invented in Vienna, Austria in 1927 by Eduard Haas III, its name is derived from the German word for peppermint: PfeffErmintZ. The small, brick like candies are sold in the billions each year but it’s the plastic, collectible dispensers that have made the brand famous. Often depicting cartoon versions of characters from film and television, they have also infiltrated pop culture, appearing in shows such as Buffy The Vampire Slayer, Japanese manga Bleach and having a whole Seinfeld episode named The Pez Dispenser in their honour.

constellations_other.name: Wild Stallion Mountain: Genre Mash-ups
constellations_other.description: The Bombay Royale are known for combining funk, disco and pop with the sounds of classical Indian music together with the soundtracks of Bollywood cinema. Their music videos similarly hybridise  genres and styles to create intoxicating visual mash-ups.

results.title: Pewter
results.creator_credit: British Foundation Pictures and Ronald Haines
results.brief_description: A study of the pewter industry in Great Britain, showing where the industry grew up and why, how the processes are carried out, and why today the pewter industry has all but disappeared in Britain.
results.description: A study of the pewter industry in Great Britain, showing where the industry grew up and why, how the processes are carried out, and why today the pewter industry has all but disappeared in Britain.

results.title: Petunia (K)
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Audio Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Petunia, the silly goose, is the self-appointed adviser to the barnyard animals. Masking her ignorance, she struts around with a book under her wing. However, when she interprets the word DANGER as “candies”, near tragedy results. Based on the book by Roger Duvoisin.

results.title: Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector
results.brief_description:
The Pettibone Mfg. Co. (Cincinatti, Ohio) patented this striking magic lantern with revolving disc in 1888 for use primarily in fraternal society lodges.
The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.
The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

-Object does not have a flue
-Lens can be extended 1.8 cm
-Internal condenser lens is a later addition and does not fit well

Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector - Ebay purchase

Original listing: https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/352469927305
From listing:
This is one that has been sitting collecting dust for many years, an 1880s dated Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) magic lantern projector. It has the stenciled triangle with the 1888 date as well as “Paragon” on the front which both sides have wear but these are actually harder to find with the painted stenciled lettering on it. The reel is full but a couple of the slides are broken but still for display purposes on a shelf looks alright. The body is the blued steel look which depending on the lighting either shows the blue look or more towards black if the lighting is bad. The front lens does extend with the turn knob and also retracts. The front lens & condensor lens are good just need a proper cleaning like the rest of this. The wood base does have some scratches which if someone were to use a stain pen you could probably fix those spots up pretty quick. Overall “G” good condition as seen with wear. The rails on this one are a brass color which the later models were just nickel plated. In back is no burner which it had been electrified so that old unit was thrown away.
results.description:
The Pettibone Mfg. Co. (Cincinatti, Ohio) patented this striking magic lantern with revolving disc in 1888 for use primarily in fraternal society lodges.

The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.

The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

results.title: Pets and people: The story of Uncle Ben's in Australia
results.creator_credit: Sapphire Films Melbourne and John Kenyon
results.brief_description: Don’t let the titles fool you - this thinly disguised documentary has little to do with people and their pets. Rather it is a piece of shameless promotion of Uncle Ben’s pet food. At times the film also looks at Albury - Wodonga - however one comes to realise that such a focus is looked at only in terms of Uncle Ben’s community involvement. Once you locate the essence of the film, what you see that is really about is a decentralised industry, quality control and general propaganda.
